This is shown (again) in the very scene you showcase, where the beast refuses to fight and we're supposed to show sympathy or  that. 

Also, the beast in his human form is "not" traditionally masculine but (true to his inner nature) almost feminine.

So I'm a senior college student and I'm currently taking a gender class because I needed a writing course. My teacher suggested we watched this video for our discussion, this was my response: 

"I can see how masculinity is glorified in these films, but I don't see a reason why it shouldn't be. Mulan could not have played the awesome female hero role if she never toughened up, it's a war movie, and she came out on top. In fact, most of these films are depicting good vs. evil so there has to be dominance somewhere for the films to be realistic. The characters aren't meant to shake hands and get along, these movies are meant to show hardship and the payoff from it. Also, I believe it's a good thing to encourage athleticism among children, so physically attractive characters like Hercules should be seen as motivation to exercise. It's unlikely that most people will resemble a Disney character, so the argument of the ideal look doesn't fully translate, but the body type should be sought in a realistic fashion because obesity should never be encouraged. Good people should be accepted, but unhealthy habits shouldn't be encouraged."

I feel this video took it's examples grossly out of context. 

1) Kuzco is supposed to be an ass-hat. The whole point of his movie was him learning to be a better person. 
2) Gaston is his movie's villain, but this video acted like he was the hero of his movie.
3) Of COURSE Mulan quickly learns physical power is important: she joined the army and was expected to FIGHT for her life.
4) Male lions DO fight in real life for dominance over their Prides (not the trait - the group of lions). 
5) Of course Hercules was chiseled: he's a greek demigod, who was actually extremely buff is his real mythology. 
6) The fight between Jafar and Aladdin, while having a little focus on Jasmine's love, was mainly to save Agrabah, the royal family, and potentially the world. 

I understand Sexism, Strength, Dominance, Masculinity, and Feminism is important, especially when critically reviewing movies. However, I feel Disney movies, and Disney as a whole, gets a lot more heat then it rightly deserves, especially when people forget not only when some of these movies were released (some as far back in the '50s), but also the time periods in which they were set.

commentThread.commentText: The extreme differences between the nemeses and the hero need to show opposite aspects that will create more conflict for the plot line.  It has nothing to do with the perspective of which you assert.  It's necessary for Aristotillian concept of the 3 Unities where conflict drives the plot, conflict on every level, even between the characters and their descriptions, the elements that distinguish their inner and outer strengths, their inner and outer conflicts, their inner and outer needs. and their inner and outer motivations.  I don't see how you can assert a point which threads into the essence and elements of screenwriting bias for or against anything.  If you intend to water down the characters in this fashion then the plot will also water down to nothing as well.

replies.commentText: also you do make a lot of good points so don't think I'm trying to discount the whole video.

Let's also remember that this movie also features a). a very threatening, very powerful female antagonist and b). a mother of two who whoops her ass while several months pregnant.

In fact, most of these examples come from the comic relief character or the villains, i.e., characters we're not meant to identify with (or, in the case of Kuzco, someone who we want to see learn his lesson).

The praise of masculinity in Mulan is not the creators talking, it's the characters, and it's important for that expectation to be established so that an un-masculin woman can defy everyone's expectations and prove that anyone is capable of great things.

The perceived stereotype that an unwillingness to fight means weakness has no validity whatsoever: it's clear in Beauty And The Beast that the Beast's unwillingness to fight makes him superior to the bloodthirsty and violent Gaston. And the only reason Scar doesn't fight is because he actually IS a coward. Think about it: the only time he fights is when he can make the first strike. Any other time he backs down or tries to weasel his way out, like when he tried to pin Mufasa's death on the hyenas. Aladdin was also not fighting Jafaar for Aladdin, he was trying to save the entire city from Jafaar's evil, power-drunken reign. Jafaar is the only one who sees Jasmine as a prize, while Aladdin actually gets her to help him (as in, he sees her as a person who can do things, not a nice thing to look at).

While I agree that masculinity is a bit overly-glorified, especially in kid's films, Disney's crimes are arguably not malicious ones, just maybe a little thoughtless. More often than not, DreamWorks films (or, more recently, Illumination Entertainment films) tend to pass of sensitive males as prissy, wimpy and comical to the point of almost being "no homo" jokes. If there are any serious examples of over-glorified masculine stereotypes in Disney films, none of them are here. I also realize this thing was made a few years ago, before "Frozen" gave us a burly, round-jawed and sensitive love interest with Christophe.

Don't write this off as just a movie so quickly. A great piece of art (and yes, this is art, even if it's not necessarily high art) can have immense influence, whether one things so or not, and art for children can shape their entire lives. So yeah, parents need to let their kids know that, it IS just a movie, but they shouldn't assume that it's meaningless.

  It should also be noted the Peter Pan is effeminate and clever, no obvious muscles shown.  When making a point, it is wrong to leave out obvious contradictions.  

  Again, I agree with this point, but it is so badly made, that I find myself defending Disney, the opposite of my normal position.  If you make a point badly enough, you do more harm than good.

Sorry bud, but half your evidence about men comes from the characters that are the villain of these films, particularly everything you said about Gaston (except about his body type, but even that was used to accentuate his cruelty). Your argument about Hercules, as evidence of Disney lauding strength, is invalid as well since Hercules is an ancient Greek story about a demi-god who's only superpower WAS HIS STRENGTH.

You also take the song from Mulan out of context. This song serves to inform the child audience of the soldier's current mindset, which sets the stage for the big reveal when the truth about her gender comes to light. And again, later in the film, the audience is shown that their sexist view was wrong.

Your use of Gaston cornering The Beast does not prove your point either. The film, here, shows the vileness of Gaston in contrast to The Beast's growth as a character (who has by this time embraced more positive qualities such as kindness, patience, and caring). Gaston is the cautionary tale, not the aspirational one.

Aladdin vs. Jafar - The final battle of every movie is a struggle of the hero and the villain. And since Jasmine was reviled by Jafar, Aladdin was not fighting to win her like a trophy, but to save her from a creep 50 years her senior who was about to force her to become his child-bride and usurp her kingdom. She was also instrumental to their victory.

I am not disputing this, as I completely see your point. However, I would also argue that in a fair few Disney films, the context is very much historical (citing Aladdin and Mulan as prime examples). Both of those films are set at a time when it was the accepted thing to treat women in such a way, and, in Mulan's case, to have these standards in place for men. I by no means agree with it, but I think it does need to be considered that historical accuracy is sometimes a factor.

And notice also that he repeatedly uses Gaston (an antagonist, not a protagonist) as an example of his points.  That is flawed logic, as an antagonist is NOT an idealized character.

The examples I listed where only a few; there is also Alfredo Linguini and Carl Fredrickse, to name a few.  And please explain why someone not getting the girl, a character being young/a child, a character who turned handsome only at the end, or anthropomorphism invalidates my points?

There is no flawed logic here.  Even if this portrayal of men in Disney films is not true 100% of the time, it is true most of the time, and in a very clear and consistent way.  That's the point.  And think about WHY there are exceptions and what variation in circumstances is responsible.  Notice that Quasimodo doesn't end up with Esmeralda, Pinnochio, Mowgli, and Peter Pan are children, Robin Hood is an anthropomorphic fox, and the Beast turns back into a handsome prince at the end of the film.

"The climactic scene of most Disney films is a battle between two men.  A violent battle to win the love of a woman or maintain pride and status is the most important scene in establishing which of these characters is the better man."
I'm not sure Disney frames their battle scenes on these relational subtexts. There's a much higher likelihood that these "climactic scenes" are more representative of good vs. evil. Isn't that something we should teach our kids - to stand up for what's right?

"When Mulan joins the army ..., she is taught very quickly that masculinity is defined primarily by strength and physical prowess."
Once again, context is important. Yes, the song is called "I'll Make a Man Out of You," but the application is to soldiers, not men - it's a training montage after all. Of course soldiers (men and women) should be capable individuals. The real lesson here is that Mulan achieves her goals on her own in spite of gender stereotypes. That's empowering to little girls.

"Often, the message to boys ... is that men should view women as objects of pleasure, or as servants to please them."
I disagree.  Context is important - the men in the films that do so are usually the antagonists ("bad guys") or have obviously amoral characteristics. In most (if not all) cases, these characters are clear examples of what not to be.  The archetypal "good guys" usually cherish and protect their chosen love, and they are selfless in doing so. Such are good examples to follow.

What's important to remember, as others have already said, is that these issues about race, gender and class are not black and white. Alladin,  isn't (overly) muscular, but he is still very westernized (fair skin, called "Al") when put next to the evil Jaffar, who bears clear arab traits.

This video is a tad sensationalist, but the top comments are so grossly simplyfying the matter it makes my skin crawl.

Most, if not all, of these arguments are invalid. I won't flood my comment with examples but just to name a few:

 - The intended message in Mulan is that women are just as capable as men and that physical beauty is only skin deep. 
 - Hercules is about having strength of heart, not about a muscle bound hunk.
 - Belle is an independent woman with a strong mind and a big heart, while Gaston is a pompous fool whose ignorance ultimately destroys him.

Sexism isn't so black & white.

@MissMeowMeowMeowMeow It's very illuminating that attempting to "defend" these stereotypical images and tropes actually exposes their prevalence and power. For instance, here we see various posters trying to point out the "exceptions" to the rule, but *that's* exactly it--that's what makes it the *rule.* Also, making excuses for these images, or contextualizing them, only matter if we *are* doing that--critically explaining and understanding them--particularly where our children are concerned.

@dyunaar1989 Actually, the villainization of Gaston was much more a degradation of his working class masculinity, not hegemonic masculinity itself. We see that Belle falls inlove with a hyper masculine brute who is in many ways, worse/more violent--the Beast. In fact, it is not Beast who challenges that stereotype, it is Belle's attention to him, her "taming" of him that softens his performance of violent masculinity. Further, while adults can see these images with more complexity, can children?

Meanwhile, in the past 20 years, Disney has been pushing a watered-down feminism. The female lead, who is often the protagonist, is one woman who is different from the rest of the girls in her stifled world. No one understands why she wants to read books or fight or think for herself. All the other girls are just looking for a good man. So the heroine inevitably runs away from her provincial confines and uses her intelligence and hidden strength to save the day for the foolish men around her.

Additionally, you don't focus on the primary male roles in these films. Look at The Beast. He's a misshapen, deformed man who dresses in fancy clothes and keeps a bunch of singing, fabulous furniture as his servants. He puts up a "manly" front by being angry, but upon further exploration, he keeps a rose petal around as a reminder of the sins of being "too manly," which is why he was cursed to begin with. He's Disney's first emo prince. Gaston is intended to be a caricature of masculinity.

You use the behavior of villains and the comic relief in these movies to explain your preconceived notions of what Disney is doing to brainwash children. Gaston is portrayed as a vain pig, and the men in Mulan demonstrate how stifling stereotypes about women can be (after all, the central message of Mulan is that women can be badass too).

Media doesn't solely decide what we do or how we think, but it definitely plays a role in shaping our concept of unquestioned societal roles and expectations--as does going to school, reading a book, talking to your neighbor, etc.

I don't mean "effects of media on individuals" in terms of moral right and wrong or even on children specifically, and your misinterpretation shows you really have no clue what I'm talking about.

I mean effects as in what our society naturally accept as "common sense," ie that heterosexuality is the norm, that there are gender roles, that capitalism is the best, that our concept of democracy is ideal, that one should embrace all aspects of Americanism, etc etc.
And I wasn't intending to sound condescending either, fyi, sorry if that's how you read it.

When you stop thinking in terms of "character and development" and start thinking in terms of the effects of media on the individuals perception of societal expectations, then you can join the conversation. You try to make it too cut and dry. The entire concept of a normative society is that it works through hegemony--through the invisible influence of expectations and a subtle subversion of the individual by presenting societal concepts as widely accepted and associated with other things, the "good guys."

They are sexist, but they are still good. If the theme is that sexism is wrong and that there are no boundaries, then why is it shown in a positive light, with no absolutely direct rebuttal?

While the protagonists may defy expectations, the world is still presented as one ruled by masculinity (or possibly other normative values of sexuality/nationalism). The viewer may see that she is able to do the same work as a man (although see one of my earlier comments on my thoughts about that), however the viewer also sees that society expects and appreciates certain aspects of women, regardless if it is right or wrong. In fact, many of the characters who say sexist things are the good guys
And I'm saying your wrong. You personally are unable to separate the protagonist and the message he or she represents from the portrayal of the world surrounding him or her.

What you fail to see in all your arguments, T, is that the message of the movies (Beast as peaceful, Aladdin as skinny--although these are more the exception than the norm) are not the only things that people get out of the media. The problem with this video is not the thesis, but the way that it argues its premise. Disney creates a disturbing amount of rigidly defined gender roles in its films. The examples, especially Gaston and the Emperor, are highly debatable as "Ideals", considering Gaston is the villain, and the Emperor a buffoon. Their portrayal of masculinity in their films is not ubiquitous, but their portrayals of women as objects or servants are far more uniform.

The issue is not that they are set in a particular time period, but that they are being shown to a modern audience. Children will pick up on these strictly defined gender roles and re-enact them in their lives.

You're right, at the end of the day, even though Gaston is protrayed as undesirable, he still gets his ass kicked by the beast. Just think if Belle killed him instead.

But the point is that the audience is not expected to admire these characteristics. In many cases the video criticizes protrayals that are meant to make the audience dislike a certain character or show stupidity.

Though Disney movies have admirable messages of character, kindness, and strength they also have many misrepresentations. In the end you can't exactly say that the child who watches these movies understands the message or doesn't absorb some of the wrong values presented in the villans who are often comical or attractive and in some cases even amicable.

It could be said that message is damaging to both boys and girls by saying boys can be violent and though women may protest they will stay, and girls should stay with men even when they are violent, because they cannot properly express themselves.

Also in the Beauty and the Beast it is first established that Gaston, whom WE later realise is a clod, has admirable qualities and the drives of an average man. And the beast, whom we later realise is kind, is first portrayed as a violent ugly creature. The beast even lashes out at the slightest offense yet Belle (a person who is EXCEPTIONALLY kind and forgiving) sticks around to endure his outbursts whereas a normal person would surely run away.
In fact when Mulan's noble deed (taking the place of her injured father) is found out she is removed from the army and would have been killed had she not saved her commander (an exceptional deed).

The point of Mulan as I see it was to show the story of a girl who went AGAINST the "norm" for the greater good of her family. However in going against the "norm" it essentially establishes what is "normal" and what is expected of girls. In addition the movie notes that Mulan is an EXCEPTIONAL character who WE realise should be immulated, yet tells kids they can only hope to immulate by setting her above standards.
